item.title: The Lede: News Web Site in Egypt Abruptly Shuts Down
item.description: The country’s premier independent English language news source ceased publication on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK

item.title: Parents Say Boston Bombing Suspects Are Innocent
item.description: At an emotional news conference, Anzor and Zubeidat Tsarnaev made accusations of a conspiracy theory and refused to accept the possibility that their children committed such an act.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anzor and Zubeidat Tsarnaev, the parents of the two men accused in the Boston bombing attacks, sat next to Patimat Suleimanova, a relative, at a news conference on Thursday in Makhachkala, Dagestan.

item.title: At War Blog: A Mortuary Affair in Iraq
item.description: Teresa Fazio, then a 23-year-old Marine lieutenant, describes her affair with a man who worked in the battalion’s mortuary affairs unit in Anbar Province, Iraq.
item.dc:creator: By TERESA FAZIO
item.media:description: Teresa Fazio was a Marine lieutenant on a seven-month deployment in Anbar Province in Iraq.

item.title: UN Approves Peacekeeping Force for Mali
item.description: The Security Council unanimously approved a new U.N. peacekeeping force for Mali on Thursday to help restore democracy and stabilize the northern half of the country.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: On Anniversary, North Korea’s Bluster Continues
item.description: The threats came after days of relative quiet, which followed weeks of warnings that dire consequences would ensue if the United States and South Korea provoked the North.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: WORLD: Chuck Hagel on Syria’s Chemical Weapons
item.description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel says U.S. intelligence analysts have determined that Syria used chemical weapons.

item.title: Death Toll Rises After Building Collapse in Bangladesh
item.description: Rescuers continue to find survivors of one of the country’s deadliest disasters.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 25
item.description: The lawns surrounding the Taj Mahal in Agra, Uttar Pradesh, undergo beautification.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: The Trans-Atlantic College Search
item.description: What happens when an American family lives overseas and it’s time to shop for college? A writer who specializes in higher education and his daughter begin their search. Has your family navigated this process?
item.dc:creator: By D. D. GUTTENPLAN

item.title: Death Toll Rises After Building Collapse in Bangladesh
item.description: Rescuers continue to find survivors of one of the countries deadliest disasters.

item.title: Science Study Shows Monkeys Pick Up Social Cues
item.description: A study published in Science showed that monkeys conditioned to eat a certain color corn switched to a disliked color when other monkeys were eating it.
item.dc:creator: By PAM BELLUCK
item.media:description: An adult male and several juvenile Vervet monkeys feeding on corn that has been dyed pink.

item.title: Iraqi Premier Urges Calm but Vows to Continue Military Strikes
item.description: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki warned on Thursday that the growing sectarian conflict in Iraq could lead to a civil war like the one raging in Syria.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO

item.title: Israel Downs Drone Possibly Sent by Hezbollah
item.description: The Israeli military said it felled the drone as it was flying south from Lebanon along the Mediterranean coast.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: India Ink: On Being Brown in America
item.description: Dark-skinned people may still be misidentified as terror suspects, but the future of America is brown, author argues.
item.dc:creator: By AMITAVA KUMAR
item.media:description: After initial footage of the suspects in the Boston bombings was released by the F.B.I., rumors started that one of them was an Indian-American student.

item.title: U.S. Says It Suspects Assad Used Chemical Weapons
item.description: In letters released to Congressional leaders, the White House said United States intelligence agencies now assess, with “varying degrees of confidence,” that the Syrian government has used chemical weapons.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Three More Tibetans Die in Self-Immolations
item.description: The latest deaths bring the total number of Tibetans who have killed themselves by fire since February 2009 to 119, said Radio Free Asia.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Jerusalem Court Upholds Ruling in Women of the Wall Case
item.description: Rejecting an appeal by the police, the court ruled that five women detained for wearing men’s-style prayer shawls and singing at the Western Wall were not disturbing the peace.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: U.S. Unsure of Chemical Arms Use by Syria
item.description: The White House said on Thursday that U.S. intelligence agencies now assess, with “varying degrees of confidence,” that the Syrian government has used chemical weapons.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, in Cairo on Wednesday, said the United States would not be rushed into action on Syria.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Swiss Quotas Highlight Europe’s Immigration Debate
item.description: Under pressure from a populist campaign, the Swiss government has moved to curb migrant numbers from the European Union. The debate in Switzerland has echoed a growing anti-immigration mood elsewhere in the Continent.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS

item.title: Israel Releases New Details of Death of ‘Prisoner X’
item.description: A judge found evidence of negligence by the prison in the case of an Israeli spy known as Prisoner X, but the chief prosecutor said there would be no indictments.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: U.S.: Did Boston Suspect Slip Under the Radar?
item.description: The Times’s Michael S. Schmidt discusses the investigation of the suspected bomber Tamerlan Tsarnaev, including what his parents said on Thursday in Russia.

item.title: Way of the World: Optimism Dims for U.S. Middle Class
item.description: The chief preoccupation of middle-class Americans, according to a new poll, is not the dream of getting ahead but the fear of falling behind.
item.dc:creator: By CHRYSTIA FREELAND | REUTERS

item.title: Syria Claims Disruption of Rebel Supply Lines
item.description: The government in Damascus claimed to have overrun a bitterly contested town east of Damascus, but rebels disputed these assertions.
item.category: National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and ALAN COWELL

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: And the Oliviers Will Go to . . .
item.description: The IHT’s theater critic handicaps the field for this year’s Laurence Olivier Awards, London’s version of the Tonys.
item.dc:creator: By MATT WOLF
item.media:description: Johnny Flynn (Viola) and Mark Rylance (Olivia) in "Twelfth Night" at the Apollo Theatre in London.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Director Mira Nair
item.description: On the filming of “The Reluctant Fundamentalist,” post 9/11 America and the “twin cities” of Delhi and Lahore.
item.dc:creator: By SHIVANI VORA
item.media:description: Mira Nair at the Tribeca Film Festival in New York on Saturday.
